body.div:
Chap. 18
Alas! reflection in the
^
my present situation was
impossible
one in which all
volun
tary
thought
was
swallowed
up and
lost.
– I was hurried away by fury –Revenge alone
inspired endowed
me with strength, & power of action
& composure –It
modelledmy feelings & allowed me to be calculating
and calm when otherwise
at periods when otherwise delirium or death
would have been my portion. My first resolut
ion
was
to quit Geneva for ever.–My country whichwhen
I was happy & belovedwas dear me
^
nowin my adversity
became hateful
I provided myself with a small sum of money
together
with a few jewels
that which
had belonged to my mother
& left it. departed
And now my wanderings beganwhich are to
cease but with life –I have traversed a vast
extent portion
of
country the earth
and have endured all the hardships
that which
travellersin desarts& barbarous countries
are wont to meet –How I
^
have
lived I hardly know
for many times
did have
I
lie
stretch stretched my failing limbs
onthe sandy plain
exhausted & far from succour,& prayed for
death –But revenge kept me alive –I dared
not die& leave my adversary in being.—
When I quitted Genevamy first
a labour
was to gain some
^
clue by which I might trace
his the
steps
^
of my fiendish enemy . But my plan was unsettledand I
wandered many hours aroundthe confines
of
Geneva the town
uncertain what path
to I should
pursue
As night approachedI found myself at the
entrance of the ceme r t ary,where William, Eliza
beth and my father reposed –I entered it &
approachedthe toom tomb which marked their
graves. Every thing was silentexcept the
leaves of the treeswhich were gentl e y
rustled
agitated by the
breeze —The night was nearly dark and the
scene would have been even to an unin
terested observer affecting and solem m n
–the
spirits of the
d departed seemed to flit aroundand
^
to cast
a
gentle hallow
shadow
which
was felt but seen not
a round the head of the mourner. But
the deep grief
that I at first
which this
scene had
at first
excited
felt quickly gave
way to rage & despair –They were deadand I lived –Their
murderer also lived& to destroy him I must drag
out my we weary existence. I knelt on the earth
and with a quirveringlips exclaimed – Bythe
Sacred earth
^
on which I kneel on ,by the shades
^
that
I wander
near me.By the deep & eternal grief that
I feelI swear — And by thee oh night and by
the spirits that preside over thee I swear
to pursue the dæmonwho caused this misery
untillhe or I shall
fall perish
in a mortal
conflict –For this purpose I will preserve
my life —To execute this
^
dear
revengewill I again
s b ehold the sun&
^
tread the green herbage of earth
which otherwise should vanish from my
eyes for ever –And I call on youspirits of
the dead& youwandering ministers of ven
geance to aid me & conduct me in my
work. Let the cursed & hellish monster
drink deep of agony – And his heart Let
him feel the despair that now torments
me.
I had begun my adjurationwith
solemnity& an awe thatalmost assured
me that the shades of my murdered friends
heard & approved my
oath devotion –But the
possessed me as I concluded it&
I was
^
rage choaked
my utterance.I was answered through the
stillness of night by a loud & fiendish laugh–
It rung my ears long and heavily; the
mountains re-echoed itand I felt as if
all Hell surrounded me with mockery
and laughing—Surelyin that moment I
should have been possessed by frenzy
and have destroyed t my miserable
exis
tence, But
but that my vow was heardand I
was reserved for vengeance –The laughter
died away and
^
when a well knownand detested
abhorred voiceapparently close to my ear ad
dressed me in an audible whisper – Iam sa
tisfied, it said, miserable wretch,you have
determined to live& I am satisfied –I darted
towards the placefrom which the moon sound
proceededbut the
wretch
^
villain
devil eluded my grasp.
When suddenly the broarddisk of the moon
aroseand shone fullyupon the dæmon
who fled. hisghastly & distorted shape, as he fled with
more than
mortal speed.
I persued
^
him;
– & for many months this
pursuit has been my task.
g G uided by a slight clue
I w followed the windings of the Rhone
but vainly – The mediterranean appeared
andby a strange chanceI saw the fiend
enter by night& hide himself in a vessel
bound for the black sea – I followed him
I knew the
vesselin which
he was concealed
&he escaped me
I know not
how.
Along the Amidst the wilds of Tartary&
Russiaalthough he still
escaped evaded
me
I have ever followed in his track – Some
times the peasantsscared by hishorrid
Apparitioninformed me of his path
Sometimes he himself who feared that
if I lost all trace Ishould despair & die
oftenleft some mark to guide me –The
snows descended on my head& I saw the
mark print
of his huge step on the white plain –To
you are fast enterringon life, &care is new to you&
X
X agony unknown
how can
I describe you understand
what I have felt& still feel.
Cold, want&
thirst
^
fatigue
were
my the least pains
which I was
destined to endure;
I was cursed by some devil& boreabout
with me my eternal Hell –Yet still a
spirit of good followed & directed my steps <surface lrx="5138" lry="7032" partOf="#ox-frankenstein_volume_ii" ulx="0" uly="0" folio="80v" shelfmark="MS. Abinger c. 57" base="ox-ms_abinger_c57/ox-ms_abinger_c57-0160.xml" id="ox-ms_abinger_c57-0160" sID="ox-ms_abinger_c57-0160"/> <graphic url="http://shelleygodwinarchive.org/images/ox/ms_abinger_c57/ms_abinger_c57-0160.jp2"/>
andwhen I most murmuredwould suddenly
extricate me from my seemingly insur
mountable
difficulties— Sometimeswhen
natureovercome by hungersunk under
the exhaustiona repast was prepared for
me in the desartthat restored & inspirited
me– The fare indeed was coarse such as the
peasants of the country lived on ate
but I
maynot doubt that it was set there
by the spirits I had invoked to aid me. Often
when all was dry and the heavens cloudless
& I was parched with thirst –a slight
cloud would bedim the sky –shed the few
drops that revived me, & vanish.
I followedwhen I couldthe courses
of riversbut the dæmon generally avoided
theseas it was here that the population
of the country chiefly collected–In other
s places human beings were seldom
seen& I generally subsisted
by
^
on the wild
game
animals
that crossed my path –I had money
with me& gained the friendship of the
villagers by distributing itor bringingwith
me some
a beast
^
food that I had killed
whichafter taking a small partI al
ways presented to those who had provided
with fire & utensils.
^
for cooking
My lifeas it passed
thuswas indeed hateful to me& it was
during sleep alone that I could taste
joy – Ohblessed sleep! oftenwhen most
miserableI sunkto repose& my dreams
lu lulled
^
me even to rapture –The spirit
that guarded me had surely provided
these momentsor rather hoursof happi
ness that I might retain strength to
fulfilmy pilgrimage without them I should
Deprived of this
respiteI should
have sunk under my hardships & misery
but during the day I was
^
thus sustained &
inspri
ted by the hope of night; & sleep – I then
for in sleep I saw
my friendsmy wife& my beloved country
again I saw the benevolent countenance
of my
b father,–heard the silver
s t ones of
my Elizabeths voiceand beheld Clerval
enjoying health & youth – Oftenwhen
wearied by a toilsome marchI persua
ded myself that I was then dreaming
^
until night should come &
that reality I
^
should then
enjoyed reality when I was again
in the arms of my dearest friends–What
agonizingfondness did I feel for them–how
did I cling to their dear formsas sometimes they
^
pursed
haunted
even
the visions of
my waking
hours my m d ay as well as night dreams
and per
suade myself that they still lived.At such
moments the vengeancethat burned
within g medied in my heartand I pursued
my path towards the destruction of the dæ
mon more as a task enjoined by heaven,
X
X as the mechanical
impulse of
some power of which
I was
uncon
scious,
thanthe ardent desire of my soul.
What his feelings were whom I pur
sued I
hardly cannot
know – Yet
s S ometimes indeedhe
left marks in writing on the barks of
treesor cut on stonethat guided me,
& instigated my fury — Myreign is not yet
over, he said waslegible
on in one of these
^
inscriptions– – You live &
mypower is complete. Follow me –Iseek
the everlasting ices of the northwhere you
will feel the misery of go cold & frost but
I shall not for cold is sweeter to me
than heat–
to which I am
impassive
You will find near this place
if you follow not too tardily, a dead
hair hare
eat& be revived. for I Come onmy enemy
we have yet to wrestle for our livesbut many
hard & miserable hours will you spend
untill that period arrives"—
Scoffing Devils!Again do I vow vengeance
again do I devote theemiserable fiendto
torture & death never will I leave omit my search
untill he dies or I, perish. –And then with what
extacy shall I fe join my Elizabeth &
those who even
^
now prepare for me a the
reward for of my tedious &
horrible
pilgrimage
As I pursed
^
still
my journey still to the
northward s the snows
^
thickened, & cold encreased to an
almos
to
in
aedegree almost too severe to support.
The peasantrywere shut up in their hovels
and only a few of the most hardy ventured
forth to seize the animals whom starvation
had forced forthto seek for prey. The rivers
were covered with iceand no fish could
be procured.The triumph of my enemy
encreasedwith the difficulty of my labours
One en inscription that he left was in
these words – Prepare –your toils only begin –
Wrap yourself in furs& provide foodfor
we shall soon enter ona journey where
yousufferings will satisfy my everlasting hat e red "My cou
rage&perseverance were inspired with
new strengthby these difficultiesI resolved
not to fail in my pur
p ose andcalling
heaven to support meI continued with
unabated fervour to traverse immense
desarts untillthe occeanappeared at a
distanceand formed the utmost boundary
of the horizon – Oh How unlike it was to the
blue se e a sof the southCovered with iceit
was only to be distinguished from land by
its superior wildness & ruggedness—Thegreeks wept
when they sawthe mediterranean from the hills
of Asiaand hailed with rapture the boundary of
their toils –I did not weepbut I knelt down &thanked
my guardian guiding spirit with a full heart
for conducting mesafety towardsthe place where
I hopednotwithstanding my adversarys threatto
meet & grapple with him — For some weeks before
this
period I had procured a sledge & dogsand thus traversed
the snows with inconceivable speedI know not
whether the fiend possessed the same advantages
but I found thatas before I had
^ daily lost
in the
advantagein my persuitI now gained on him
so much that when I for the first time
saw the occean–he was but one daysjourney
in advance& I hoped soon to intercept him
With new courage thereforeI pressed on& in
two days arrived at a wretched hamlet on
the sea shore.I enquiredconcerning the fiend
& gained every information –Agigantic devil
monster
they saidhad arrived the night before –Armed
with a gun and many pistols &putting
^ to flight the inha
bitants of a solitary cottage to flight through
fear of his horr terrific appearance, he had
seized on
carried off their store of
wn winter food
&placing it in a sledgeto draw which he
had had
seized on a numerous drove of trained
dogs –he had harnessed
^
them –& the same night
had to the d joy of the horror struck villagers
had pursued his journey across the the sea
in a direction that led to no land& they
conjectured that he must be speedilydestroyed
inthe breaking of the iceor frozen by the
eternal frost.–
On hearing this informationI suffered a tem
porary fitof despair –he had escaped meand I
must now commence a destructive & almost
endless journey across the mountainous ices
of the occean – amidstcold that few of the
inhabitants could long endure& how could
whih, I ex
a
the native of a genial & su
^
n ny climate
could not hope to survive. Yet at the idea that the
fiend should lif live & be triumphantmy
rage and vengeance returned &like a
mighty tideoverwhelmed every other fee
ling.After tasting a slight reposeduring
which the spirits of the dead hovered round
me& instigated me to toil & revengeI
prepared for my journey.
I exchanged my land sledgefor
one fashioned for the ruggednessof the
frozen ocean andpurchasing a plentiful stock
of provisionsI departed from land. How
many days have passed since then I know
notbut I have endured misery that
which
nothing but the eternal sentiment that
of a just revenge burn s ing
within my heart could have enabled
me to support. Immense & rugged moun
tains of ice often barred up my par
barred up my passageand I often heard
the
^
earthquake & the thunder of the
ground seawhich threatened my
destructionbut again afrost came that
secured me.
&made the
paths of the
sea,secure.
and I followed the slight
tracts that my enemy had left –By the
consumation quantity of provision
^
which I have consumed
I should guess
that I had passed
three
two
months three weeks in this
journey –And
despair despondency & grief–
often wrung bitter
drops from my eyes — Despair indeed had
almost secured her prey & I should soon
have sunk under this misery– When once
after the poor animals that carriedme along had
with incredible toil gained the summit of an ice
mountain Th they paused to rest and one unable to
move sunk
^
sinking under the toil died—I f viewed the expance
before, with anguish;when suddenly my eye was
arrested bya dark speck on
^
the dusky plain –I strained my
sight to
view discover what
indee it could be& uttered a wild
cry of extacywhen I distinguished a sledge dogs&
a hideous
^
the distorted proportions of a well known
form moving away
^
within.
Oh hope with what
a burning gush did hope revisit my heart –warm
tears filled my eyeswhich I hastily wiped away
that they might not
^
be present in them to
intercept the view I had of the
fiend. I followed—but still the dewdimmed my
sight untillgiving way to the emotions that
oppressed meI wept aloud.
But this was not the time for delay
I disincumberedthe ir dogs of their dead
compa
nion and gave them a plentiful portion of
food andafter an hours reposewhich was abso
lutely necessary& yet which was bitterly irksome
to meI continued my path —The sledge was
still visiblenor did I again lose sight of it
except at the moments when for a short time
some ice rock
hid concealed it
^
from with its intervening crags. I indeed perceptibly
gained on
it. the object of my pursuit.
And after about amo ano
ther
weeks days journeyI beheld myselfat no
more than
two leagues half a
league mile
distant. from it
My heart bounded within me –But
nowwhen I appeared almost within grasp
of my enemymy hopes were suddenly extinguished
and I became lost all trace of him more
utterly than I had ever done beforeA ground
sea was heard –the thunder of its
^
progress
as it the wa
ters rolled & swelled beneath mebecame every
moment more ominous & terrific —Ipressed on
but in vain ly –The wind arosethe sea roared
andwith the mighty shock of an earthquake
it sp i li t& cracked with a crash tremendus
and overwhelming sound —The work was
soon finishedin a few minutes a migh
ty oceanrolled between me & my enemy.
And I was left diftingon a scattered piece
that was every moment lessening
and thus preparing for me a hideous
death – thus past
In this manner many
hideous
hours
^
passed
several of my dogs diedand I myself
should have was about to
sunk
^
under the accumulation of hardships
when I saw your vessel
riding at ansh anchorand holding forth
to me hopes of succour & life. I had no
conception that vessels ever came so
far north& was astounded the sight.
bu and I quickly destroy in ed g
^
part of my sledge
I and
to
constructed oarsand by these means was
ablewith infinite fatique t o near move
my ice raftin the direction of your
sledge
vessel
I had resolved thatif you were going
southwardstill to trust myself to the
mercy of the seasrather than abandon
my purpose –I hoped to be able to move
you to grant me a boat & some provi
sion withI could still seekmy enemy.
But your direction was northward and I
now daily hope that I may gai find the
fiend I seek and sacrifice him to my revenge
or discover certain assurances of his
death destruction– In the mean time I
consent to drag on a miserable existence
uncheered but by the hope of freedom
when freed from my task of vengeance and now I enjoy the hope that I may again see him and in executing on him the vengeance
And you took me on board when life my
vigour was ex
^
h austed& death would soon have
I should soon have sunk under my multi
plied hardships toa death which I still dread ed formy
task is unfu
^
l filled. Ohwhen will my gui
ding
Oh! When s spiritin conducting me
to himallow
^
me
the rest I so much desire!
or must I die& he yet live—IfI doswear
to me, Walton, that he shall not escape
that you will seek him& satisfy my
vengeance in his death. Yet do I dare
ask you to undertake my pilgrimageto
endure the hardships that I have un
dergone. NoI am not so selfish– yet
When I am deadif he should appear
if the ministers of vengeance should
conduct him to you I confide that
you would Swear that he shall
not live – Swearthat the accumu
he shall not triumph over my accu
mulated
miseries& liveto make a
nother such a wretch as I am – Ohhe
is eloquent & persuasiveand once
his words had even power over
my heartbut trust him not–His soul
h ishellish
^
as his form
full of
malise treachery & fiend like
mali gnity ce –hear him not,call on the
manes of William, Justine, Clerval
Elizabeth, my fatherand of the Whretch
ed Victor& thrust your
dagger sword
to into his
heart– If I then
'live exist
to the knowled ge
I will hover near you& direct the steel
aright fear not that you commit an
act of cruelty – No the blood of all the innocent
that he has murdered will plead for you
